posts.name: Prince M
posts.cooked:
The idea is that alliances have transmitters on their robots or can use existing radios to communicate with each other during a match. A possible use case could be transmitting your robots' pose data to the rest of your alliance, which could potentially be used in algorithms like pathfinding to avoid alliance robots. Or even near the end of a match instead of shouting what your robot is going to do (like climbing or parking), you can simply transmit the information, and your alliance can have code that acts accordingly.

Even if this isn't legal right now, would FIRST Robotics Competition possibly be open to making it legal in the future, or even standardizing robot-to-robot communication like this?

Personally, I think this would only benefit the overall competitiveness of FIRST Robotics Competition.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: R707 is what would currently prevent this. That said, in a hypothetical future where inter-robot communication was allowed, I would suggest against using a separate transmitter/receiver system and instead using the existing wireless network. Currently, each team’s network (wireless from field to robot and wired from DS to field) is segmented apart by VLANs. There’s nothing saying FIRST can’t open up some form of communication across VLANs. Perhaps open a single port between VLANs for the same alliance and build something into WPILib to enable communication/data sharing over that port. The biggest problem with doing something like this is that it requires teams to communicate and agree on a data format. For it to work, it would need to be standardized in some way, which is why I suggest it be built into WPILib and just toggled on/off depending on team preference. Teams can be given control over what types of data should be shared and perhaps the source of those values, but the data structures should be standardized.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: R707 and R706 can potentially be circumvented using field radios along with innovative programming within the Operator Console. However, R904.A may pose challenges that could complicate this approach. Implementing such a workaround without assurance against potential complications could lead to increased scrutiny or involvement from higher levels, similar to a CSA/FTA or HR inquiry. Therefore, it's crucial to verify the viability and safety of this method before proceeding. Consulting recent guidelines or seeking insights from those who have successfully navigated this scenario would be advisable. Until confirmed as reliable, the decision to implement remains uncertain.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
I don’t see how R904 (operator console size/shape/etc) fits into this scenario. R706/R707 explicitly prohibit any form of network traffic aside from the usual Driver Station (DS)<->Robot communication via Field AP.

If you're considering something but prefer not to share it publicly, feel free to direct message me. I'm genuinely curious because, under the current rules, I don’t see any viable alternatives.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: R706/R707 only prohibit wireless communication.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: Extremely Important: Do not bypass the Arena network. All signals must originate from the Operator Console and be transmitted to the Robot via the Arena Ethernet network. Each Operator Console is responsible for controlling its own Robot legally through the Arena network and is listening on a second local network for echoed telemetry data, which appears to be permissible. Additionally, you could potentially tether between Robots and communicate directly; however, unless it’s a game like 2015, expect opposing alliances to attempt to cut the wire or encounter issues with the tether being outside the starting configuration or extension limits. To set up effectively, use a separate local network switch and provide your alliance members with a second Ethernet adapter for their PCs. Isolate this setup to a specific subnet to avoid interference with your Robot network or the regular Ethernet adapter used by the Driver Station (DS). Ideally, connect the Driver Station (DS) to the Field Management System (FMS) first before establishing your local network party connection. Be prompt to avoid slowing down the Field and begin setup immediately. Once connected, you can communicate with each other, share Robot data, and route information through Robot-to-Driver Station-to-Robot paths. Avoiding wireless communication altogether will yield better bandwidth and control compared to relying on the Field network infrastructure. Notably, R706 pertains specifically to communication between Operator Consoles and Robots, not general inter-Operator Console communication. Always adhere to the Arena network protocol to ensure compliance and functionality.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: In quals, you need a significant number for it to be useful. In elims, there could be value for just 3 (or even 2) to adopt.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: R706 is crucial for communication between the operator console and the robot via the ARENA Ethernet network. It does not involve wireless communication. Specifically, R706 handles signals from the operator console to the robot and ensures they follow the designated path through the ARENA network. This system is specifically designed for direct communication between the console and the robot, ensuring efficient and reliable transmission. The mention of "all signals" refers to the type of communication managed by R706, not necessarily restricting it to wireless methods.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Surely you agree that two drive coaches could talk to each other during a match without violating R706.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Depends on the definitions of “signal” and “originate”. The signal (e.g., packet) sent to the ROBOT still “originates” in its respective Driver Station (DS), even though it is generated based on information other than human input. It is generally agreed that transmitting a camera stream from the robot to the Driver Station (DS), performing image processing on the Driver Station (DS) side, and then sending a signal back to the robot based on that process is permissible, except under the restrictions outlined in G402.

Another potential approach involves utilizing the visual spectrum—for instance, having one Driver Station (DS) display a QR code to another Driver Station (DS)'s camera. While R905 does not explicitly exempt vision-based solutions, it does allow for motion control via a Kinect. Therefore, one Driver Station (DS) could wave a flag while another uses a Kinect to detect it. Historically, sending visual information from the field to the robot, such as during the Power Up competition, was considered legal. However, it is unclear whether this exemption was deliberately narrowed in scope.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Yes, I agree if we're talking specifically about the letter of the law, that's technically an exception. However, given the title of the rule, “Don’t bypass the ARENA network,” I'd say it's safe to assume we're talking about electrical signals here.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
If we asked the QA whether they could provide a useful answer or if we'd receive a 'We can't provide input on a hypothetical concept' type response, what would define the boundary?  

Considering an IP camera monitoring drivers and processing the image on a DS (Driver Station) to control the robot, with the laptop connected to a separate camera outside the arena's control system—even potentially on a different subnet—I achieve the same outcome. Using either a built-in webcam on a DS laptop or a plug-in USB device suffices. As long as all signals directing the robot pass through the DS and conform to official protocols, why would such a setup be deemed illegal?

To me, the arena shouldn't need to be part of every process. You can run external software on your computer to interface with custom controller boards via Arduino, handling data through serial connections or functioning as a direct HID keyboard, then remapping inputs as joystick buttons. Why does using a hard-lined Ethernet connection and TCP/IP-based protocols differ in this context? The arena isn't required for this functionality and would only introduce unnecessary latency during processing.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: To effectively address the network setup for the team, it's advisable to establish a dedicated local LAN to ensure a secure and reliable internal network. Each alliance member should be equipped with a second Ethernet adapter to enhance connectivity and potentially improve load distribution or redundancy. When selecting network hardware, prioritize switches with ample ports to accommodate the number of devices and connections required. Consider using Ethernet adapters that offer additional ports or built-in switching capabilities to support multiple users simultaneously. Ensure the setup aligns with existing infrastructure and integrates security measures like subnets or firewalls. Additionally, evaluate how the chosen hardware impacts the operator console's performance, whether through increased port capacity or physical space considerations. This comprehensive approach will optimize network efficiency and meet the team's operational needs.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: The USB cable connecting our controller to the laptop’s USB hub is longer than 5 feet and we got away with that on-paper violation every match. If a cabling length question is the concern here, perhaps the driver will have to hold the switch to make it legal.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: R904B states "excluding any items that are held or worn by the drivers during the match."

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: So if the drivers on both teams hold onto the Ethernet cable, rules lawyering is fun!

posts.name: Daniel G
posts.cooked:
The text is: **EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLANATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH.** The text is:

Actually for R904, since OPERATOR CONSOLE is defined as “the set of COMPONENTS and MECHANISMS used by the DRIVERS and/or HUMAN PLAYERS to relay commands to the ROBOT”, I would ask whether the neighboring “operator console” (common sense definition) with which a team’s “operator console” is communicating becomes a part of that team’s defined OPERATOR CONSOLE. Surely the drivers are using information it produces to control the robot. In the same way, a screen showing a dashboard is part of the OPERATOR CONSOLE because the drivers are using it.

Granted, this is an expansive definition of “use” - a more restricted definition would contain only COMPONENTS and MECHANISMS that are specifically for the purpose of commanding the robot, like the driver’s laptop. But “use” probably contains “use indirectly”, and I’d rather not be the one trying to argue otherwise to a ref. (This still seems silly. Is the tray on which the laptop sits being “used”?)

However…

Peter_Johnson:

So if the drivers on both teams hold onto the Ethernet cable?

so the drivers on both teams need only hold each others’ computing devices used to send the communication as well!

Wait… that only saves you from R904B (depth) not R904A (length). Ah well.

This begs the question, if I projected a hologram that showed information to the drivers that extended more than 6 feet and 6 inches off the ground, surely that would be allowed? Can a COMPONENT be intangible?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: the field reset life chose me (6201M, 3419A)

posts.name: Joe Johnson
posts.cooked:
I don't want to hijack the thread, but I think the next logical step that FIRST could take is to have the robots on an alliance all be able to publish information to each other. I think there could be some standards developed for message contents and formatting (such as robot pose, robot velocities, and maybe even some way for the robots to communicate planned pathways).

I don't think this would add to the capabilities of robots in the first year that such things were implemented, but over 2 or 3 years, I suppose you'll see tons of really cool behaviors that are not possible today.

data.title: Is it legal to have robot-to-robot communication?
